text: THUNDER RUMBLES and LIGHTNING FLASHES... YOUNG LAWRENCE, a raven-haired youth, 10 years old, sits in his bed, looking fearfully to the darkness.

With the STORM HEARD raging outside, Young Lawrence peers out into the HALLWAY. A man's ANGUISHED CRY is HEARD, but it's lost in the SOUND of THUNDER. Was it imagined? Young Lawrence, in a night~-shirt, starts tentatively dow the long, dark hall of this opulent, Victorian MANOR HOUS LIGHTNING illuminates many big game, ANIMAL HEAD TROPHIES mounted one-after-another: TIGER... ELEPHANT... LION... Young Lawrence walks, trying to ignore the freakish table
Young Lawrence slows, looking ahead to... a DOOR ajar. LIQUID pools out from beneath, like black molasses. Young Lawrence moves to push the DOOR OPEN...
A MAN is slumped on his knees, weeping, cradling the FIGU of a WOMAN. He lets out another CRY of anguish!

Father... ? The man, SIR JOHN TALBOT, 40, looks to see Young Lawrence Sir John is in agony, tears streaming down his face. The cradled WOMAN'S ARM falls free, dangling limply, the wrist slit; gashed wide with BLOOD FLOWING to the floor. Young Lawrence stumbles back in horror... Falling against his older brother, BENJAMIN, 12, arriving the doorway. Benjamin, likewise terrified, raises a brigh OIL LANTERN to the room just as BOOMING THUNDER is HEARD!

The stately MANSION and surrounding countryside are glimp in brilliant LIGHTNING. THUNDER ECHOES as we... SOAR UP into the TEMPEST! CAMERA Z00MS: through and beyon roiling STORM CLOUDS... to find a FULL MOON shining down.
CLOSE ON: a stage-craft FULL MOON backlit by flickering gaslight within a painted BACKDROP of crooked trees and g sky. INTO FRAME steps handsome LAWRENCE TALBOT, mid-30's.

(as Hamlet) To be or not to be. That is the question. Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer, The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune... Other ACTORS are SILHOUETTED in nearby SHADOWS. COSTUMED Lawrence walks to centerstage, passionate eyes gleaming.
Or take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them. To die: to sleep. No more; and by a sleep to say we end... IN THE AUDIENCE: wealthy WEST-ENDERS watch, enthralled.
The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks, That flesh is heir to: 'tis a consummation, Devoutly to be wish'd. To die...

TOLLING hauntingly, BIG BEN is faintly seen in the gloom this bleak Victorian horizon of endless BUILDINGS, skelet industrial CRANES and soot-spewing SMOKESTACKS. INSERT TITLE: "London, 1888" While on the near STREETS, THEATER-GOERS pour noisily out from the THEATER into filthy, loud, over-crowded Londonto
eee ONEGHT A boisterous PARTY is HEARD from the other room. Lawrence sits at his DRESSING TABLE, in costume, pouring two stiff DRINKS. He hands one to a tawdry COCKNEY LADY beside him.

Over the lips and through the gums... They drink. Cockney Lady laughs, already drunk. Lawrence pours again while Cockney Lady paws at him amorously. A fatherly, ELDER ACTOR, American, enters from a curtained CHANGING BOOTH, pulling on his jacket, watching them.
A few cocktails, Lawrence?
A few.
Too many?
Et tu, Brute?
No. Indulge, by all means. Just do not forget yourself. Lawrence toasts his own REFLECTION in his MIRROR.
I make no promises.
The occasion is in the other room. Bring your new... friend. Elder Actor exits. Lawrence extricates himself from Cockn Lady's grasp, kissing her hand as he stands.
Excuse me, dear, while I dress.
Dress. Undress. Whichever you like. She smokes. Lawrence begins changing from his COSTUME. Behind, the DOOR opens as a lovely woman, GWEN CONLIFFE, looks in, nervous. She KNOCKS, clears her throat.
Begging your pardon, sir... I... Lawrence is taking off his SHIRT as he looks over. Gwen is stunningly beautiful, in a nice, though plain, DRESS. She tries to avert her eyes from his shirtlessness
I'm... terribly sorry, but... you are one Mr. Talbot?
Correct.
Mr. Lawrence Talbot, actor? Lawrence pulls on a SHIRT, buttoning.
Correct again, and while normally I'd be so happy to make. the acquaintance of an admirer as lovely as yourself... (of Cockney Lady) ..-tonight, as you can plainly see...
You misunderstand me.
Do I? Well, make it quick. I'm about to have my hands full.

I've come from Talbot Hall. West Blackmoor. My name is Gwen Conliffe. Betrothed to Mr. Benjamin Talbot. Lawrence regards her with a new seriousness. Gwen nods. Gwen makes way as Lawrence shows Cockney Woman out the do
My brother's fiance? Lawrence considers, looks to Cockney Lady.
A moment alone, please...
What's all this about?
Go entertain yourself. I'll collect you momentarily.
So, Miss Conliffe... what brings you here tonight?

You've had no letter from Benjamin lately, though you expected one. Forgive my reading them, but your last correspondence with him told me you'd be in London now. (troubled pause) The reason there's been no letter... Benjamin is gone. He's disappeared.
Disappeared?

For almost a month now, without a trace. And there's been a killing in Blackmoor; an unspeakable murder. All the while, a certain woman is at the center of it. Because of her, propriety forbids me from saying anything more. (pause) I come to ask for your help.
My father. He knows you came?
He knows.
He asks this? My father?
I ask. I pray you will return to Talbot Hall. } Lawrence turns away, sullen, slowly shakes his head.
I cannot.
You must. Please. How... how can I express what heartache it's been...?
Tonight was our last performance before returning to New York. ! Besides which, whatever this is... i what help could I be in any of it?
With respect, where else would you have me turn? It is your family in dire need of you.
I'm sorry you've wasted your time. For my own reasons, I will never go back to Blackmoor. I'm afraid that's | my final word. Gwen stares sadly down in weary despair.
Well, then. There's nothing more to say. Except thank you for hearing me, Mr. Talbot.

Lawrence watches as Gwen crosses. She halts at the door. GWEN . I know you've been away for nearly a lifetime. Still... he is your blood. Your only brother. Gwen goes, SHUTS the DOOR. Lawrence stands alone, miserab cur To:

ee EE eee NG Lawrence, in his Hamlet COSTUME, walks these swampy MOORS amidst a heavy FOG. MIST swirls as he reaches out.
Hello...?! Ahead, within a CIRCLE of huge, weathered and ancient STO MONOLITHS jutting upwards from the ground, Lawrence nears A lone MAN in rural attire, standing with his back to us.
Benjamin, is that you? Ben...? As Lawrence approaches, the MAN TURNS to REVEAL... A FACELESS VISAGE of unbroken flesh stretched ‘taut acros SKULL of empty EYE SOCKETS and gaping maw!
Lawrence awakens, aghast, sweaty. He sits up, looking beside him to Cockney Lady who lies facing away.
Lord... what a dream. You awake? Cockney Lady GROANS sleepily, stirring...
I dreamt I was in a fog, and... Cockney Lady TURNS, showing a GHOULISH SKULL-FACE devoid features -- SHRIEKING -- her TEETH GNASHING!
Seems Lawrence awakens for real this time, sweaty, gasping. As he looks to Cockney Lady who lies facing away beside h he scrambles from the bed, backing fearfully to the wall.

text: A ROOFTOP HATCH is thrown open with a THUD. Lawrence clim a LADDER out onto the flat ROOF, wearing clothes he's thr on. He takes out and lights a CIGARETTE, inhales deeply. Lawrence goes to the roof's edge. He takes out a BOTTLE, drinks. He stares across the dark London CITYSCAPE set against the aborning, orange SUNRISE. His mind is trouble

(under his breath) Damn you, Father. Goddamn you. Lawrence angrily flings the BOTTLE at the horizon. it's HEARD SHATTERING far off, shards HEARD scattering. A distant TRAIN WHISTLE SOUNDS, growing LOUDER... cur TO:

We find MEMBERS of Lawrence's ACTING TROUPE unloading many large TRUNKS of "Atherton Traveling Theater Co." belongings fro WAGONS. STATION ATTENDANTS help transport the TRUNKS insi Other ACTORS slap Lawrence on the hack, wishing him well, Elder Actor comes to firmly shake Lawrence's hand.
We'll do the best we can without you. It's right this; you going home.
No home of mine, but I'm going. Hard to believe, one long day's journey takes me back 20 years.

Good luck. See you in New York. Lawrence nods, waves as he crosses the STREET... This is post-Industrial-Revolution London, with the SOUND of INDUSTRY echoing in the sooty air; London as the cente of the universe. Streets bustle with hurried GENTLEMEN an LADIES, shouting HAWKERS, dirt-poor WAYWARD YOUTHS and BEGGARS. As Lawrence reaches a waiting four-horse CARRIAG the DRIVER opens the passenger door. Lawrence climbs in.
SE eee Lawrence's CARRIAGE crests a hill, leaving LONDON hazily distant. Much beauteous COUNTRYSIDE lies ahead.
The carriage moves swiftly through dense, sun-dappled WOO
——— SEE i eee ee DAL IN THE COUNTRYSIDE, under Blackmoor's (perpetually) GREY SKIES, Lawrence's carriage veers left at a FORK in the DI ROAD. The other road leads to the VILLAGE on the horizon.

— ELE UN MOTION) ~~ DAY Lawrence peers pensively out the WINDOW... Scanning the bleak and forbiddingly vast MOORS. Low, wild heath and peat dominate this desolate, boggy WASTELAND. The STONE MONOLITHS from Lawrence's nightmare command an area of high ground. Cawing BLACK CROWS congregate.

— EEE CERES _ON ~~ _DUSK The driver guides Lawrence's carriage onward. Beyond near FIELDS, a GYPSY ENCAMPMENT of TENTS and WAGON has settled an open area bordered by FOREST. CAMPFIRES burn. GYPSIES lead HORSES, carry WATER and skin wild GAME

At one exotically decorated WAGON, an ancient, female fortune-teller, OLD MALEVA, steps out, sensing something. Stooped Old Maleva hobbles purposefully across the encampment, past other TRIBE MEMBERS who respectfully mak way. She reaches a vantage point from where she can SEE.. The DISTANT ROADWAY where Lawrence's carriage is passing. Old Maleva's piercing eyes narrow, fixated.
The carriage at last passes under a vine-entangled STONE GATEWAY with a barely discernible "TALBOT" hewn into it. The long, ESTATE ROAD ahead is canopied by mighty TREES.
—_— BL MONTAGE ENDS Amidst once-impressive, now-neglected ORCHARDS... TALBOT MANSION looms; majestic, though it's glory days ar long past. Two-storied. Two wings. Weathered and aged.
With the carriage heading away in the B.G., Lawrence sets down his TWO SUITCASES. He gathers his nerve, straighteni his clothing and hair. Hesitant, he KNOCKS, entering...

The DOOR CREAKS, as Lawrence enters. He passes through the wood-paneled ENTRY PARLOR, CROSSING into the giant, Victorian-Gothic GRAND HALL. It's a cavernous room, with walls covered floor-to-ceilin in TAPESTRIES, PAINTINGS and all manner of displayed WEAPONRY; RIFLES, LANCES, SHIELDS and crossed SWORDS. Across the way, two STAIRCASES combine at a LANDING to le up to the West and East Wing BALCONIES of the second-stor Lawrence crosses, FOOTSTEPS ECHOING. There is a look and feel here of cobwebby, frayed-edged, smoke-darkened gloom and decay, as there will be everywhere throughout Talbot House. Gothic indeed. Everywhere, magnificence wanes. Lawrence comes to stand before the Grand Hall's massive FIREPLACE, staring up at the OIL PAINTING hanging above.. A PORTRAIT of his MOTHER; a youthful, olive-skinned beaut standing on the moors, her dress and raven hair flowing.

"I will arise and go to my father, and I will say unto him...!" Ris reverie broken, Lawrence turns to see... Grey-haired, dashingly handsome SIR JOHN TALBOT, mid-60's striding down the STAIRCASE, his mellifluous voice boomin

"Father, I have sinned against heaven, and before thee! And I am no more worthy to be called thy son; make me as one of thy hired servants!" Sir John reaches the bottom of the stairs, followed by hi ioyal DOG, an old hunting hound, SAMSON. Sir John is an imposing presence; a WELL-DRESSED man of the gentry, desp the odd worn cuff here and loose seam there.

And lo and behold, here he stands: [ the Prodigal Son returned. Shall I i have my own robe brought to be placed upon your shoulders? Rings for your fingers and shoes your feet? Shall I kili the fatted calf?
Don't go to any trouble on my account.
Come, let me see you. Let me look at { what kind of man you've become. Lawrence walks to face Sir John, clears his dry throat. i
Hello, Father.
Lawrence. They look at each other, no more than ten feet between th silence hanging like a challenge. A chilly reunion.
Words fail me. When your telegram arrived to say you were coming, I couldn't bring myself to believe it. I've grown so accustomed to thinking I would never lay eyes on you again.
As have I. Sir John SMILES wryly, walks to cross the vast room.
Of course, to be clear... it wasn't my idea to send for you.
I wouldn't have imagined so.

Not that you're not welcome, of course! We'll make room for you... (to his :DOG) -+-won't we, boy? It's only that... I simply can't help wondering... Sir John yanks a dusty, tasseled BELL PULL several times.
What difference could possibly be made by your being here? A fair question, I think. Lawrence considers, restraining his anger.
I'll do whatever I can, I suppose, to aid my missing brother...
How noble you are!
Although, knowing so little yet, how can I give the answer you seem to want from me, Father?
ll.
Let me be the one to enlighten you. Sir John turns on his heel, SHOUTING, so his VOICE ECHOES
(disgruntled) Where in the hell...? Entering through one ARCHWAY beneath the STAIRS, comes th balding and pasty butler, KENDALL, exasperated.
Yes, Sir John, yes. Here I am.
Wonderful, Kendall. Lawrence here will be our guest for... however long. Take his things up. Have Gwen meet us in the drawing room. cur To:
EEE EEE —E——EYr Eee In the dark, cluttered, high-ceilinged DRAWING ROOM, Sir John pours much SCOTCH into TWO GLASSES on a LIQUOR TRAY.

Blackmoor's troubles began the day the wandering caravan arrived. Late- winter, ten months ago. Lawrence looks up at ANIMAL HEAD TROPHIES, SAFARI PHOTOS, and WORLD MAPS adorning the walls. Sir John places one drink on a TABLE near Lawrence, goes to sit in a CHAIR by the blazing FIREPLACE which Samson lies near.

The Gypsies are quite willing to make a living from us; telling fortunes, trading and peddling goods. But, since many villagers still believe all Gypsies to be witches, a distance is kept. Although... it is rumored that, amongst the gentlemen of Blackmoor... Lawrence looks at one PHOTOGRAPH: of YOUNG LAWRENCE and YOUNG BENJAMIN standing with MOTHER and SIR JOHN.

Some men of questionable morals, upon a hunting excursion, or out for an evening's constitutional, may discreetly make their way to the Gypsy encampment. There they are welcomed to partake of wine, women and song. Well... maybe not song. At the DOORWAY, Gwen gives a small cough, entering timidl There's no denying her fair beauty. Samson goes to her.
Good evening. Sir John stands to be polite...
Hello, Gwen. -..and immediately sits back down. Lawrence gives a nod.
Hello.
I didn't expect you'd come. Please... don't let me interrupt. Gwen pets Samson. She crosses to a corner, looking small.

Six weeks ago, a Gypsy named Victor; a blackguard and thieving criminal, finished serving a lengthy prison term in London. He returned to the tribe, only to find his Gypsy wife far along in a pregnancy.
The child was not his?

His absence was too great. And so, this Victor dragged the unfortunate woman, Carmilla, into the village. He brought her before our Justice of the Peace, saying Blackmoor parish owed him justice. A CLOCK begins CHIMING. 7:00. Sir John stands.
Seven o'clock already. We must leave.
Leave? Where are we...?
Sir John's already striding out the door.
——— OO EE mR TO ON EGHT Sir John walks from TALBOT HOUSE. Lawrence and Gwen follo ON THE LAWN, ahead, a STABLE BOY brings THREE HORSES.
Why would this husband go outside his tribe? Unless, he felt the village did the wrong to him.
Exactly. Victor had beaten a confession out of his wife. She told how her secret lover was one of the men of Blackmoor.
She will not say who it is.
For which she's spent the last month and a half jailed; to be held until she tells his name.
You still haven't said what all this has to do with Benjamin. Gwen's troubled, unable to bring herself to say it. . Lawrence sees this. Sir John is likewise saddened...
Benjamin is suspected.
As the father? It cannot be true.

Squire Strickland has called a Public Hearing for tonight. I must be there to speak for your brother. Sir Lawrence and Gwen go to take their horses' reins. Sir John climbs ably up onto his great, WHITE STALLION. Stable Boy gives Gwen a boost as she mounts her horse.
You can still ride can't you, Lawrence? Sir John and Gwen ride towards the ESTATE ROAD. Sighing, Lawrence takes his horse, climbs expertly on. He rides.
oo Ee GET Sir John, Gwen and Lawrence ride abreast.
Benjamin's no adulterer. He's not capable of such treachery.
On that the three of us at least agree. However... on the first full moon night during Carmilla's imprisonment, there was a killing...

text: ———— EE Eee EE MORNING Now with the FARMERS and CONSTABLE in the distance, we se a_ SMEAR of BLOOD on one STONE MONOLITH. A man's SEVERED HEAD lies nearby, neck ragged, EYES WIDE. FLIES swarm.
SE Se ROAD ~~ NIGHT Sir John, Gwen and Lawrence ride on.
Done by some... beast. Or made to look like it.
The peasantry claim a devil-creature was called by a curse placed on us by Carmilla; or was conjured by those Gypsies sympathetic to her plight.
They say a Loup-Garou stalks the witching hour of the full moon.
A werewolf? Are you serious?
Whoever committed the murder did so to stir superstitious fears, in the hope that Carmilla would be set free.
It was one day after the killing, when Benjamin went missing.
Found gone, some of his clothing and belongings taken. As if he'd fled.
And he said nothing before he left? He gave no indication...?
No, he... he said nothing. Lawrence watches her, senses something. She averts her ga
Are you certain?
He said nothing.
The longer he's gone, the more rumors spread and fester. So, tonight... to defend Benjamin means defending the gypsy Carmilla. cur TO:

— a EEE ES eee As the DOOR of the JAILHOUSE opens, an O.S. CROWD is HEAR REACTING. The very pregnant Gypsy, CARMILLA, in SHACKLES, bewitchingly lovely déspité her pale, ailing appearance, lead out by the gorillalike JAILER. Sir John follows, gri The CITIZENS of Blackmoor pack the lamp-lit, COBBLESTONE STREETS of the SQUARE; mostly poor, peasant FARM FAMILIES Some SHOP WORKERS, LABORERS and SERVANTS. An awesome GUARDIAN ANGEL STATUE -- wings spread, SWORD raised -- Stands at the crowd's center. SHOP OWNERS watch from the DOORWAYS of the bordering TAVERN and STOREFRONTS. WIVES a DAUGHTERS lean out 2nd-story, residential WINDOWS.
Carmilla is lead down a few steps, facing the crowd, her green eyes fearful. Sir John follows to stand with her.
At the JAILHOUSE DOOR: out struts the haughty magistrate, SQUIRE STRICKLAND, 60, long-haired, immaculately bedecked

Lawrence and Gwen climb the tiered BASE of the ANGEL STAT to stand where they can see over the gathering. Behind the crowd, in the open-air FORGING WORKSHOP of his BLACKSMITH SHOPPE, the brawny, Irish blacksmith, JAMES FITZGERALD, comes to watch. He's soot-covered, in a leath APRON. His WIFE joins him, cradling their infant CHILD.
Strickland surveys the crowd, raises a hand. CROWD QUIETS
My friends... we all know why we are gathered here. (pointing down) This man has suffered an injustice...

AT THE FRONT OF THE CROWD, given wide berth by VILLAGERS, stands VICTOR, Carmilla's thuggish, Gypsy husband, wearin an EYEPATCH. He's flanked by Old Maleva, the fortune teller, and BELA, the gaunt, waxen-skinned Gypsy Chief.
A great wrong was done to him. Done by this woman... his own wife! Carmilla hangs her head, her features bathed in cold swea
She carries a bastard child conceived in the sinful act of adultery.

The CROWD MURMURS, agitated. Beneath the TAVERN'S "Sword God" SIGN, several of the town's more elderly and most wealthy GENTRY stand watching: the distinguished DOCTOR LLOYD; the broad-shouldered, walrus-moustached COLONEL MONTFORD; and the wizened, dour-faced PASTOR FISK. Other plump, drunken LAND OWNERS stand amongst them, DRINKING.
Strickland plays to the cheap seats always.

She refuses to say who in Blackmoor Village is the father. Why is that? Has it something to do with the full moon evening, when blood and gut were spilled onto the moor!? And what about the note; secretly nailed to this very door in the dead of night one day later...?
Strickland thrusts out a PIECE of PAPER... A scrawled NOTE and DRAWING of a PENTAGRAM: "RELEASE HER
A threat made against us all, with the next full moon tomorrow!
Beyond the ANGRY CROWD, lanky CONSTABLE NYE (seen in the FLASHBACK) arrives on his BICYCLE, PIPE in mouth.
Who made the threat? For us to find the truth, she must confess her fellow adulterers name! As the CROWD VOICES assent, Strickland glances to Sir Joh
UNDER THE STATUE, at the CACOPHONOUS center of the SHOUTI CROWD, Lawrence and Gwen look around in despair.
Sir John steps forward, facing the gathering, raising his hands. The CROWD begins QUIETING, respectfully.

Please, if I may...! You all know me. You know the Talbots have and always will be one of the pillars of this community. JI am an honorable man. As such, I must ask again... by what law, Squire Strickland, is this woman held, when adultery is no crime?
Yes, well... I'm not surprised you'd like to see her freed and forgotten, Sir John. Wasn't it your son said to have frequented the Gypsy camp? (more)
Your son; Benjamin, who was witnessed in heated arguments with this woman, and who visited her while she was jailed...?
What kind of man are you, to make such accusations against my son?!
These are facts, not accusations. The crime is economic! Should this forgiving husband be left unfairly responsible for the financial burden of the bastard child? I think not.

That is the reason you pretend so you may exert your puritanical will. You wish to disgrace whoever dared to have relations with a lowly Gypsy! So you overstep the bounds of your authority by jailing her, while you slander my family's good name!
If that is what you truly believe, let the debate be opened to all... {addressing the CROWD) If there is anyone who also feels this woman is.the aggrieved party, say so now! Make yourself heard!
Except who would dare speak against you, aS you are principal landowner and Justice of the Peace?

Nonsense. Yes, many are indebted to me... but everyone knows I am a fair and open-minded man. They know they can speak freely, so... (addressing CROWD) Again; if you side with her, as Sir John does, speak! You think I am unjust? I Beg you, raise your voice!

UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence and Gwen look to the surroundi crowd as EVERYONE grows HUSH. AT THE BLACKSMITH SHOPPE, James Fitzgerald watches, empathetic. He sets his jaw, steps forward, about to spea His WIFE reaches to stop him. He sees the fear in her eye
AT THE TAVERN, the GENTRY exchange sheepish looks (excep stone-faced Fisk), knowing they will not speak out.
In the silence, Carmilla shuts her eyes, shedding a tear. Strickland, arms out, turns to Sir John.
A telling silence. Deafeningly so. Sir John can say nothing more, solemnly defeated.
(from across the square) My brother is innocent!
EVERYONE TURNS en masse, looking... UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence stands at Gwen's side.

I am Lawrence Talbot, and I would stake my life that Benjamin is not the father. Whoever is... can't you see she's trying to protect you...?! (imploringly, to VILLAGERS) How can you keep silent while she suffers this way, all to save you from harm? I beg you, reveal yourself ALL AROUND Lawrence and Gwen, not one person speaks. No o

Another heartfelt, familial plea. Alas, met aiso with an empty sound. (turns to Carmilla) If she will not tell, so be it! We hold her longer still! As the Jailer steps forward... Carmilla stands, in shackles, tearful.
No! No more! I'll tell... The GASPING CROWD returns all attention to Carmilla.
I'll tell you all! I'll keep the secret no longer! The CROWD'S QUIETING as Carmilla looks to the apprehensiv Sir John. She wipes tears, looks out, gathering courage..

It is Benjamin... Benjamin Talbot. You have my confession. As the CROWD REACTS, EVERYONE TALKING... SHOUTING... i AT THE BASE OF THE STAIRS, Victor's enraged, charging up Stairs towards Carmilla! The Jailer steps up to block the way -~ shoves Victor back! Bela comes to restrain Victor. Strickland's smiling, triumphant. He nods... The Jailer walks to take Carmilla's arm, pulling her up t steps. Sir John bows his head, stricken, despairing.
UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence and Gwen are stunned.
No! It's... it's not true. Gwen climbs down, distraught, PUSHING through...
Gwen! Gwen! She SHOVES past villagers, running away into the CROWD. Cur TO:
A smoke-filled meeting of.town elders. Strickland, Doctor Lloyd and Colonel Montford sit at a TABLE, drinking. Othe fat LAND OWNERS smoke, drink and whisper amongst themselv
Tomorrow comes the full moon. Do you let the whore go or not?
If I'm permitted to speak in my good | friend Sir John's defense... The BARKEEP serves more BOOZE. Sir John is seated by the FIREPLACE, staring into his MUG, brooding forlornly. i i
You needn't defend anyone, Doctor. i We're all on the same side. I more i than anyone wish Ben would appear. |
You know how it looks, Sir John. There are those who believe Benjamin's hiding away, till she's released and the gypsies go. Even more think he is the murderer...
Pastor Fisk
I don't give a damn what people think! To hell with them all!
W...well.
(to Strickland) Still, it does seem your crusade has reached its end, Squire, with the man she's implicated nowhere to be found.

I know where he is! You want to know?! That lost soul's spellbound in her curse; out in the wilderness somewhere, living like a mad animal... till the full moon calls him again to do her red work! You'll see, tomorrow night! observes, by the BAR where Constable Nye leans.
Please do keep that supernatural claptrap to yourself!
No. There may be something to it. EVERYONE looks to spooky Pastor Fisk, QUIETING.
The devil is able to touch our world. There are Such demons that walk like men, and men who walk like demons. Silence lingers, the FIRE HEARD CRACKLING.

Well, I'm not certain what that means, but if she's still jailed by the Quarter Sessions, there'll be hell to pay. Beg pardon, Pastor Fisk. (to Strickland) She's made the confession you demanded, hasn't she?
The note said others will die!
Yes, Colonel, but we don't know who left the note, who did the murder, or even if they are the same person!
Enough. Enough! (sighing deeply) Let the full moon rise and fall. If there's no other killing, Carmilla will be released to her husband. He may deal with her however he sees fit.
And the child? What if it is truly my grandchild she carries?
What of it? Once this is done, the tribe will move on. Feel free to follow them if you like, but they will be Blackmoor's problem no longer. cur To:

SSS EE EE EEEEEEeEe__ Lawrence rides his horse through low FOG, carries a LANTE Ahead is the fine FRAMEWORK of a far-from-finished HOUSE forest's edge. Lawrence dismounts, bringing the lantern. INSIDE THE FRAMEWORK, Gwen stares up to the STARRY SKY.
My father said I might find you here.
Welcome to... our house. Not yet a home. On the farthest edge of the your family's estate. I used to iaugh that this is as far as I could get Ben to move from Talbot Hall.
Further than I would have expected. Gwen smiles faintly, looks back up. The surrounding WOOD FRAMING describes a large, simple TWO-STORY STRUCTURE.
Not that there's been much work on it. Not lately.

text: Jack sprints out from the ALLEY, shoving by TWO burly FACTORY WORKERS. The men curse him as he continues fleein Jack trips and FALLS... SPLASHING into an enormous puddle the street, losing his HAT. He scrambles up and keeps running as fast as his legs will carry him. cur TO:

SOUNDS of EXOTIC BIRDS are HEARD. The Wolfman pulls himse up atop a tall WALL, remains there, crouched, sniffing at the night air. He drops down inside the wall. He crouches at the water's muddy edge, begins scooping wa to his mouth, drinking, ever watchful.
As the Wolfman drinks, we PULL BACK: beyond IRON BARS to reveal that this GARDEN is actually an enclosed ZOO HABIT which, according to its SIGN holds a...

“Crocodylus niloticus; Nile Crocodile." IN THE ENCLOSURE, Wolfman continues sating his thirst at pond's edge, in a rare moment of quiet calm. He stops drinking, leaning forward to peer curiously into the wate He's transfixed by his own REFLECTION for a long moment. Then, just as the REFLECTION is broken by RIPPLES... An enormous CROCODILE LUNGES UP from the water, reaching his massive jaws to CLAMP DOWN on the Wolfman's leg! The crocodile performs a DEATH ROLL, DRAGGING the Wolfman back with him into deeper water! The Wolfman's YELPING, clawing and fighting back... He SLASHES at the crocodile, managing to extricate his to BLOODY leg from the croc's craggy-toothed mouth. In the frothing water, the two behemoths WRESTLE! It's a brutally violent, life-and-death struggle! The crocodile SLAMS the Wolfman with his powerful tail... The Wolfman lands at the water's edge, dazed. The HISSING crocodile attacks from behind! The Wolfman rolls, barely. avoiding the croc's gnashing j The crocodile twists, snapping after the Wolfman... Wolfman climbs on the crocodile's back, gripping the croc head in both hands -- PULLING with all his might! Kneeled on the crocodile's back, with the savage reptile THRASHING beneath him, the Wolfman's PULLING the crocodil head back further... further still, until finally -- the crocodile's SPINE is HEARD SNAPPING grotesquely! The croc goes MOTIONLESS. The Wolfman releases his grip. The Wolfman rises, spent, staggering away from his defeat foe, bearing BLEEDING WOUNDS from the encounter. By LANTERN light, a greasy-faced, shabbily-dressed, middl aged GRAVEROBBER and his FOUR, young STREET URCHIN i accomplices (Artful-Dodger-types), strain at ROPES tied { around a COFFIN they're hoisting up from an exhumed GRAVE They manage to set the heavy COFFIN beside the open grave propping it up on the DIRT MOUND they've dug.

That's the way, lads. A little bit of effort leads to good things, aren't I always saying? (smiles his CROOKED SMILE) Now... let's see how good! Graverobber pulls the COFFIN LID OPEN. He and the Four Urchins grin in at the CORPSE of the well-dressed MAN.

Hello, Mister Sir! Glad to meet you! Pleasure's all ours! Graverobber and his urchins LAUGH, setting to work, quick and efficiently removing anything of value; taking RINGS from the man's fingers and CUFF LINKS from his cuffs. Funny, isn't it; how this here gent who wouldn't've given us the time of day when he was alive... (holds up POCKET WATCH) Is such a generous fellow dead! Graverobber LAUGHS again, but the laugh catches in his throat as he spots one of the wolves. Graverobber stands as the urchins all turn, looking... The wolves have them surrounded.

Alright, my lads... let's be calm about this... nice and caim... Graverobber licks his lips, looking to a SHOVEL sticking from the dirt mound. Meanwhile, the closest wolf begins edging forward, GROWLING menacingly.
On the count of three... run. Graverobber slowly reaches for the shovel, watching as th most aggressive wolf creeps even CLOSER...

The urchins scatter! Graverobber grabs the shovel just as the first wolf LEAPS at him! Graverobber SWINGS the shovel, BASHING the wolf aside! The YELPING wolf goes tumbling! The four other wolves all RUN OFF... Following the urchins in different directions. Graverobber raises the shovel, preparing to swing again, he's losing his footing in the loose dirt... He TRIPS backwards over the coffin, coffin LID SLAMMING a he FALLS down into the deep, dark GRAVE! IN THE GRAVE: Graverobber's hurt, groaning, trying to ris DIRT FALLS IN onto him as he's looking up... Just in time to see the COFFIN SLIDING...
Bollocks! i The heavy COFFIN SMASHES down -- CRUSHING Graverobber!
Several urchins run... |
ZIG-ZAGGING through HEADSTONES. Two of the wolves race after them!

Blondie, our favorite urchin, runs for all he's worth, st hugging the dead man's SHOES to his chest. Two ravenous wolves are right behind. Blondie glances back, terrified. Ahead, there are TWO VAULTS close together. It's a tight fit, but Blondie disappears down the NARROW SPACE between them... When the two wolves arrive side-by-side, their attempt to follow becomes a SNARLING FIGHT over right of way.

Blondie ducks down in the shadow of a massive GRAVEMARKER pressing against the cold stone, hiding. The SNARL of the wolves is soon HEARD. Blondie watches as, down the ROW of GRAVES, the two wolves arrive, prowling. The wolves SNIFF at the ground, heading Blondie's way. Blondie notices for the first time that he's still got th shoes. He swallows, deciding. Carefully trying to make as little noise as possible, Blondie THROWS one shoe... The SHOE'S HEARD landing a few rows down. The two wolves immediately raise their heads. They rush off in the direction of the sound. Blondie grins, relieved. He stands slowly, craning his ne to make sure the coast is clear. Something WET starts DRIPPING down onto his shoulder. Blondie notices, looking at the droplets... RED droplets. Blondie looks straight up... ABOVE, standing balanced atop of the huge GRAVEMARKER, is the Wolfman leering down. He DROPS, letting out a ROAR!

Amidst the boundless LONDON CITYSCAPE... The Wolfman climbs towards the peak of the spectacular DO of ST. PAUL'S CATHEDRAL. The Wolfman reaches up at the FULL MOON, HOWLING loudly.. HOWLING with a kind of disconsolate yearning.

A hard RAIN FALLS. On a high ROOFTOP overlooking the city Lawrence, in human form, lies face down, unconscious. He stirs, awakening. He drags himself to his feet, holdin his head in pain, noticing the WOUNDS on his leg. He touches the wounds, not fully understanding. Lawrence looks down at his tattered, blood-stained SHIRT PANTS. He examines his hands and forearms, which are covered in SCRAPES and LACERATIONS. There's BLOOD under h FINGERNAILS. Now, realization begins to come to him. As Lawrence turns to look out over the storm shrouded CIT the full weight of the lost evening crashes down upon him He falls to his knees, numbed by the horror of it, the RA washing over him. He breaks down ~- afraid, ashamed, enraged -- WEEPING into his hands. cur TO:

The CHURCH'S dark interior is meager in scale and adornme PEWS are empty. An elderly PRIEST lights CANDLES near the entrance. Lawrence enters, still in his wet, torn clothin slowly walking up the CENTER AISLE.
May I assist you, son?
I'll only be a moment.
Is there something you need? Do you wish confession? Lawrence stops, standing in DARKNESS, without turning.

It's a little late for that. Lawrence continues. Halfway up the aisle, he takes a seat kneeling. Pale LIGHT filters in through the STAINED GLASS WINDOWS behind a large CROSS over the ALTER. All is QUIET Lawrence puts his hands together, lowers his head.
(quietly) I'm not here to ask forgiveness. What things I've done... (more)

(pause) I don't even remember. I do know I will pay for them. I am damned. I am damned, and there will be a reckoning, soon enough. (pause) I ask one thing, though I have no right. I beg of you... let me do what needs to be done. Give me the strength I'm afraid I don't have. Lawrence looks up, hands still clasped.
Give me the courage to finish this. CuT TO:

In the PARLOR of this upper middle-class, 3-story ROW HOM Gwen works mending CLOTHING at a SEWING MACHINE. She's weary from lack of sleep. GWEN'S FATHER enters, a man of kindly appearance, wearing a look of great worry.
Gwen, dear.
Yes, Father? What's wrong?
You'd... better come.

Gwen walks down the STAIRS to the front of the house, uncertain, followed by Father. GWEN'S MOTHER, a stout, handsome woman, stands in the HALLWAY, likewise worried. Mother looks to the FRONT DOOR. Gwen follows her gaze... A FIGURE can be seen through the DOOR'S TRANSLUCENT GLASS Gwen crosses quickly, going to OPEN the FRONT DOOR... ON THE PORCH, Lawrence stands, desolate, soaking wet and shivering, holding himself against the cold. Gwen can barely believe her eyes, overcome by emotion. She takes his hands, bringing him inside, SHUTTING the DO cur TO:
FIRE in the FIREPLACE. Lawrence sits in a CHAIR, wearing clean, new CLOTHING (borrowed from Gwen's father).
He gazes into the flames. Gwen stands at one WINDOW, j watching the RAIN. A large, mantel CLOCK is HEARD TICKING

Finally... when I awoke, it was with no real memory of last night. Except, of bloodshed. An orgy of violence. (pause) The curse has been passed on from the father to the son. (troubled pause) And, there is one last thing. I'm certain that Benjamin tried to stop my father. (hesitant) I'm just as certain that my father killed Benjamin. Gwen's bathed in the day's cold, pale light.
I'm so very sorry.
As you say it... I know it's true. I've known I need to begin mourning him. (pause) I just don't know if I can bring myself to accept it. Gwen brushes away tears. Lawrence stands.
There isn't much time. I've nowhere else to turn.
What can I do?
If you can manage it, I need enough money to get a horse.
Why? Where will you go? Lawrence does not answer. Gwen realizes.
No. You can't go back there.
I have to.
You said yourself, he killed Ben... killed so many others. He'll kill you.

He has already, Gwen. He has. It will be a full moon again tonight. {looking at his hands) Even now, I feel it... like a crawling beneath my skin; a burning in my veins. I have till before midnight to get to Blackmoor and to end my father's life. And then... (pause) Then, I will do what it takes to end the curse in me. Gwen's shaking her head, agonized.
There must be some other way... {
There isn't.
There must be! This... this can't be happening!
I can't run, not from this. Not this time. There's no one else. It's my turn to be the one to face responsibility. Lawrence crosses to Gwen, his voice thick with emotion.

Nothing in heaven or on earth can change what's happened, or what happens tonight. Nothing can stop the moon. But, I'd have given anything that our paths might have crossed in some other life. If we'd have only had a chance somehow. Lawrence takes Gwen's hand in his.

I confess... there is a part of me praying that if I'm able to avenge my brother, he may forgive my feelings for you. Feelings I've fought so hard against, please believe me... Lawrence KISSES Gwen's hand. Her heart is breaking.
Forgive me.. Let Benjamin forgive me. Gwen takes Lawrence's face in her hands, presses her lips his. They KISS gently, both crying.
(quietly) Pray he'll forgive us both.
Goodbye, Gwen.
No. Please, don't go...
Goodbye is all we have left; all life ever had for you and me. (whispers) Goodbye. Tearfully, they share one last KISS.

GLOOMY SKIES. PEDESTRIANS everywhere. Streets are clogged with VEHICLES. Lawrence, wearing a COAT, makes his way do the crowded SIDEWALK, passing a young STREET HAWKER wavin a NEWSPAPER with a PHOTO of LAWRENCE under the HEADLINE: "ESCAPED MENTAL PATIENT! Brutal Killings in the Night!"

(droning sales-pitch) Read it here. Escaped Mental Patient. Escaped Mental Patient. Lawrence hides behind his jacket collar, moving on, but t he halts. Ahead, TWO POLICE CONSTABLES stroll this direction. Lawrence quickly turns, hoping he's not been seen, now facing the Street Hawker.

(still droning) Escaped Mental Patient. Escaped Mental Patient. Street Hawker does a startled double-take: looking at Lawrence, looking to the NEWSPAPER, then back at Lawrence His voice takes on a newfound urgency...
(POINTING at Lawrence) Escaped mental patient! (more)
Escaped mental patient! Escaped mental patient!! Lawrence turns to hurry back the way he came... Comes face-to-face with another POLICE CONSTABLE.

Just one moment, Mister...! The Policeman's brings a WHISTLE to his lips, putting a h on Lawrence. Lawrence grabs the Policeman's arm, TWISTING pulling him forward, then SHOVING him back! The Policeman goes SPRAWLING over Street Hawker's NEWSPAP DISPLAY and STACK of PAPERS, but he's BLOWING his WHISTLE Lawrence wheels to see... The TWO CONSTABLES reacting, RUNNING this way. Lawrence charges straight at them. The lead Constable's raising his BILLY CLUB, but Lawrence lowers his shoulder DIVES into them -- KNOCKING both Constables to the ground Lawrence ROLLS, scrambling to his feet. He RUNS... SHOVING Pedestrians... TOPPLING STREET VENDOR TABLES... He darts into the busy street... Disappearing in the CROWD.
RAINING HARD. Lawrence RIDES a HORSE at full gallop on a muddy ROADWAY, leaving LONDON behind.
The CLOCK'S HEARD TICKING. Gwen sits at the SEWING MACHIN eyes bleary from crying. She just sits there, motionless, staring at the sewing machine for the longest time.
RAINING. Lawrence RIDES full out through a dark FOREST.

Gwen's Mother and Father are seating in the SITTING AREA. She pretends to occupy herself KNITTING. He pretends to b cleaning out his PIPE over a pedestal ASHTRAY. Mother looks over her knitting to watch Father absently p a PIPE CLEANER into the pipe, his mind elsewhere.
Why don't you see how she's doing? Father looks over, tosses the pipe aside, rising.
Gwen's Father comes up-the STAIRS to a closed DOOR.
(through door) Gwen?
Gwen's Father KNOCKS, looking in...
Gwen, dear, your mother and I... The room's empty. Father's troubled, seeing... The WINDOW'S OPEN to the FIRE ESCAPE outside.
A FOUR HORSE COACH speeds away with LONDON in the B.G., on seemingly the same muddy ROADWAY Lawrence took.
Gwen frets, looking out into the DARKNESS.
Gwen's Father is at the open window. As he steps back, he notices a single BULLET beside the SEWING MACHINE.
Gwen's Father rushes in. He goes to the bed, getting on h hand and knees to reach under. He pulls out a small, meta STRONGBOX, flipping it open. It's empty, except for a few BULLETS.
Gwen takes a PISTOL from her dress pocket, studies it. cur To:
Rain's stopped. Lawrence halts his weary horse as they reach the crest of a hill, looking across the distance to
TALBOT HOUSE starkly SILHOUETTED against the sky, with th FULL MOON glowing directly above. Lawrence stares for a long, steely-eyed moment. Cur TO:

Lawrence rides his horse quickly on a FOREST TRAIL... | Arriving at the Talbot GRAVEYARD. At the GATE, Lawrence jumps down. He walks in amongst the HEADSTONES. . Mother's ornate TOMB beckons, touched by SHAFTS of MOONLI

The heavy DOOR is slowly pushed inwards, inch by inch, ti Lawrence is able to squeeze through, entering. Brushing aside COBWEBS, Lawrence sadly looks upon mother' STONE SARCOPHAGUS, which rests on a PEDESTAL. He steps forward. There's another COFFIN beyond mother's...

A plain, WOODEN COFFIN on the floor. Lawrence is filled with dread, kneeling beside this coffi He removes the LID, reacting to the smell of death. ‘ INSIDE THE COFFIN: a MAN'S ROTTEN CORPSE. Almost three months old, altered by desiccation and decay. Skeletal. Its CLOTHING is CLAWED, SHREDDED, covered in old BLOOD.
Benjamin. Lawrence swallows, tearful. He's found his brother at las He places a hand on the corpse's chest.

My brother. I'm sorry. I left you... abandoned you to him. I've regretted it for so long now. Forgive me. Forgive me, that this is our reunion. (agonized) How can it be that I never met the i man you became? How could I have let i that happen? : He stands, looking down at Benjamin's corpse.
Rest in peace. Know that what I do tonight, I do in your name. After a moment, Lawrence bends... CONT INUED oy  98. Taking the REVOLVER from Benjamin's HOLSTER. Cur TO:
Lawrence rides at full gallop towards the mansion.
IN ONE WINDOW: SIR JOHN'S SILHOUETTE can be seen as he's looking out, till he lets the CURTAIN fail CLOSED.

So eee ae Shoving the FRONT DOOR OPEN, Lawrence strides in, throwin off his COAT. He's clutching Ben's REVOLVER, crossing int the Grand Hall with its walis of PAINTINGS, CRESTS, TAPESTRIES, WEAPONS, TROPHIES; Talbot history. ACROSS THE ROOM, Sir John is seated in a CHAIR by the massive FIRE in the FIREPLACE. He holds a BOTTLE of SCOTC The room is lit by CANDLES held in CANDELABRA. j
Well, well! An unexpected visitor! You are cutting this awfully close, aren't you...? Sir John gestures behind him... Where the large GRANDFATHER CLOCK shows: 11:45.
Fifteen more minutes, and you and I won't be ourselves anymore. Or is that it; have you come to join your father for a night out on the town? Lawrence arrives, gathering his nerve, pointing the gun.
Stand up.
I'd have Kendall attend to you, but he's fled. Took my goddamn dog with him, the bastard. Have a drink? i Sir John drinks from his bottle.
Stand up, Sir!

As you wish. Sir John rises, imposing as ever. CONTINUED i  99. He's well dressed, but more disheveled than usual, unshav There's no sense of drunkenness, but the man, like his manor, is deteriorating.
Calm yourself. You're the one with the weapon, after all. I could have armed myself if I'd wanted... shot you down the moment you walked in.
Why didn't you?
(shrugs) Call me sentimental. You came all this way... you deserve a sporting chance. Sir John walks as he talks. Lawrence keeps the gun traine
You're not entirely unexpected. The asylum sent word of your "escape," though accounts varied wildly, as you might imagine.
I found Benjamin. I finally found him where you left him. This is his gun. These... his bullets... Lawrence opens the gun, takes out one SILVER BULLET.
Silver. He loaded this weapon with silver bullets... Lawrence puts the bullet back, closes the gun.

Once he realized that there was no other way to stop you. (holding up REVOLVER) i Tell me again you didn't kill him. Deny it, while I hold the proof. Sir John looks away, tortured, guilt eating at him.
The irony is... we forged those bullets together, long ago. A last resort, we agreed. One I was confident we would never need. (angrily remorseful) He put himself in harm's way. (more) |
Out on the moors, that night. I... I never meant for him to die! How should I have known he'd side with them? How was I to know he'd turn against his own father!?
Because he was so mucn better a man than you.
You'll hear no argument from me. Sir John swigs morosely from his bottle.

You killed him with one hand, buried 100. him with the other, and still managed somehow to remove yourself from blame. It was Ben's fault, because he tried to protect the villagers. My fault you attacked me, because I had been warned. Mother died not at your hands, but at the hands of the beast. (furious) All of my life... I thought this family cursed. But, you were the curse on us, Father! All along, it was you.
You come here to speak for Benjamin... to avenge him...? Sir John's still pacing.

First, answer how you can even dare call him your brother! Or did you imagine a handful of letters across the years could make up for your betrayal? Because that's what your leaving was... a betrayal! It's Lawrence's turn to face his wounding guilt.

You know full well how you wronged him... how it was as if a part of himself was torn away when he found you gone. He loved you! (pause) For those wounds you inflicted upon him... I admit could never have forgiven you.
What of the wounds you inflicted?
He may not have been able to bring himself to tell you what he truly thought of you, but Ben and I... we spoke often of your cowardice.
You needn't remind me of my debt to him. I'm here to repay some part of it tonight. Lawrence looks across to... The GRANDFATHER CLOCK. It's 11:49.
As for cowardice... it means so little coming from a man who, having torn out the throat of his beloved wife, hadn't the courage to end his own life.
Again, think what you will of me and the suffering that's been my lot. I don't expect you to believe me, but I would've gladiy traded places with your mother if I could have...
Easy to say.
As it was, my death would have done nothing more than to orphan my sons.
And all the better for it we would have been! Or have you forgotten...? You murdered us! One by one, you murdered us all! Look around! They're standing at the center of the Grand Hall.

This is what remains of the family you speak of with such reverence. Your trophies... the sound of your own voice... the ghosts of your victims. That's all you have left! Everything else you destroyed. (bitterly) All for Carmilla.
Don't you speak her name.

Her own love was proven, beyond a doubt. She suffered endless humiliations, though she could have had her freedom merely by confessing your name. But, she kept silent... to protect you. Out of love. Lawrence keeps the gun trained on Sir John.

You, meanwhile, kept a different silence. Having weighed your feelings for her against your instinct for self-preservation. You wouldn't dare risk your social standing or the precious honor of the Talbot name! So, you abandoned her to her husband's tender mercies. And she took her life... alone. Heartbroken. Sir John drinks, sunk in grief.

You were the end of her... not Strickland... not the citizens of Blackmoor! You were her reason for living and her reason for dying! Sir John wheels, THROWING his bottle... It SHATTERS against the wall!
No more! I'll hear no more!
For you to commit murder in her name and call it vengeance is a sick perversion of her memory.

(enraged) Then be done with me! Enough talk! End it now! That is a gun in your hand, is it not?! Oh, but first... first let me inform you of one small detail. You see, before you came in... I took the liberty of turning the clock back ten minutes. ZOOM IN: on the GRANDFATHER CLOCK which now reads, 11:50.

(angry mocking) So...the time you thought you had in which to screw up your courage is gone! This, son, is your moment of truth! Lawrence is unnerved, uncertain. He looks up as... The BLACKMOOR CLOCKTOWER is HEARD TOLLING from the distan Sir John steps up, defiant, pounds his chest.

Here is your chance to finally show your father what you are made of!! If you think you have it in you to pull the trigger, DO IT! Do it. Lawrence grits his teeth, angry, terrified... He's leveling the revolver squarely at Sir John's chest, the gun TREMBLES in his hand. With the far off CLOCKTOWER TOLLING, all Lawrence's years of fear of and pent-up hatr for his father culminate in this decisive instant.

When I first arrived... you asked what difference my returning to Talbot Hall could make. (pause) Here is your answer! Lawrence PULLS the TRIGGER... The HAMMER FALLS, but NOTHING HAPPENS! Lawrence and Sir John are stunned. Lawrence pulls the trigger again! Nothing! Sir John's disbelief turns to rage as he KNOCKS the gun away -- PUNCHING! Lawrence is thrown to the floor!
Good God, you did it! Lawrence tries to rise, but Sir John KICKS him down! Sir John's manic, seems almost proud.

The grave's damp must've gotten to the powder, but still... a valiant effort! I honestly didn't think you had it in you! Lawrence is on his feet, letting out a CRY as... He TACKLES Sir John! They go CRASHING through the sitting area, scattering the CHAIRS and SIDE TABLES. They fight in front of the roaring FIRE, trading blows.

Sir John's fists STRIKE like sledgehammers! Lawrence manages to block one of his father's swings, countering with a PUNCH that sends Sir John to the floor. Sir John wipes his bloodied mouth as he's rising.

Nicely done! Lawrence is immediately on Sir John, pinning him, getting both hands around Sir John's neck Lawrence puts everything he's got into tightening his STRANGLE HOLD on his father's windpipe! Sir John struggle And just when it seems like Lawrence has the upper hand.. Just as Sir John's having the life choked out of him... Sir John STARTS TRANSFORMING! His TEETH LENGTHEN and beco florrid FANGS! His reddening face GROWS its grey-tinged F while his HANDS SPROUT dense FUR and lethal CLAWS! Much to Lawrence's dismay, he's now fighting the brutally powerful GREY-WEREWOLF in MID-TRANSFORMATION! Grey—Werewo breaks Lawrence's grip, brings one leg up and KICKS -- se Lawrence FLIPPING backwards in the air... Lawrence THUDS to the floor across the room. Grey-Werewolf rises, the "change" complete. He looks around, furious and disoriented, as one might imagine. He announces himself with+a window rattling ROAR! — Lawrence covers his ears as he's getting to his feet. Grey-Werewolf turns, heading for Lawrence, nostrils flari saliva dripping from his wicked maw. Lawrence goes to a dusty SUIT of ARMOR, taking the long, deadly SPEAR the posed KNIGHT was holding. As Grey-Werewolf advances, thirsting for carnage, Lawrenc wields the spear. Grey-Werewolf doesn't seem to care or understand the spear, till Lawrence... SLICES into Grey-Werewolf's arm! Grey-Werewolf backs off bloodied. Confused. Lawrence keeps SWINGING the spear, keeping Grey-Werewolf at bay. Lawrence maneuvers over to grab an unlit OIL LAMP from a WRITING DESK against the wall, THROWS the LAMP... The oil lamp SHATTERS against Grey-Werewolf, SOAKING the of his arm, torso and beastly face with OIL. Undeterred, Grey-Werewolf advances... Lawrence is backed up against the desk, trapped.

He raises the spear -- STABBING... The spear PIERCES Grey-Werewolf below his left collar bon the SPEARHEAD bursting bloodily out Grey-Werewolf's back! Grey-Werewolf SCREAMS, staggered, clutching the spear. Lawrence runs over to the mounted GUN RACK where many of John's PISTOLS and RIFLES are displayed. He grabs a large SHOTGUN.
Grey-Werewolf grasps at the spear, but the spear's flared arrowhead-like point is impossible to pull out backwards.

Lawrence clutches the SHOTGUN as he kneels before the low long, wooden GUN CABINET. He throws the CABINET DOORS ope pulling out a heavy WOODEN BOX. Lawrence opens the box. It's filled with ALL KINDS of AMMUNITION. He grabs a BOX of SHOTGUN SHELLS, however... The VEINS on the back of Lawrence's hands THROB! FUR is starting to GROW! It's happening. Transformation's begun
Lawrence looks over his shoulder to where... Grey-Werewolf still struggles to remove the spear. Lawrence looks over his other shoulder to... The FIRE in the fireplace.
Grey-Werewolf falls to his knees, falling on the spear's shaft, which drives it further into his body!
